The famous "Tamer of two beasts"  ğ“€ª ğ“€« ğ“€¬ is a better trace symbol of [pioneers](PIE) than the [swastika](swastika)  

[Master of Animals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Master_of_Animals)  

The earliest known depiction of the Master of Animals appears on stamp seals of the Ubaid period in Mesopotamia.[6] The motif appears on a terracotta stamp seal from Tell Telloh, ancient Girsu, at the end of the prehistoric Ubaid period of Mesopotamia, c. 4000 BC. By 3500BC the "zoo" necropolis in [Nekhen](Nekhen.html) displays exotic animals as proof of power over [nature](nature.html), beast, man and [chaos](chaos.html).  

![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/59/Ancient_Levantine_God.jpg)  
![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Pendentif_minoen_%28British_Museum%29_%288704963755%29.jpg/440px-Pendentif_minoen_%28British_Museum%29_%288704963755%29.jpg)  

'He' started as a she in Anatolia as "The lady with two lions", [Potnia Theron](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potnia_Theron), "Mistress of Animals"  

30000 years early the [Lion-man](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lion-man) was an icon in much of Europe.  
Afterwards the 'Venus' was *the* trans Eurasian Neolithic figurine!  

He ğ“€ª ğ“€« ğ“€¬ is very prominent from Egypt to [Sumer](Sumer.html),[Jiroft](Jiroft.html)@Iran all the way to the [Oxus](Oxus) and [Indus](Indus) civilizations and even Europe.
